sn42.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā mallesu viharati uruvelakappaṁ nāma mallānaṁ nigamo.
sn42.11:1.1.ref: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.
sn42.11:1.1.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.

sn42.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhadrako gāmaṇi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
sn42.11:1.2.ref: Then Bhadraka the village chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn42.11:1.2.en: Then Bhadraka the village chief went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn42.11:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desetū”ti.
sn42.11:1.3.ref: “Please, sir, let the Blessed One teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.”
sn42.11:1.3.en: “Please, sir, let the Blessed One teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.”

sn42.11:1.4.pli: “Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, atītamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ:
sn42.11:1.4.ref: “Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the past, saying
sn42.11:1.4.en: “Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the past, saying

sn42.11:1.5.pli: ‘evaṁ ahosi atītamaddhānan’ti, tatra te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
sn42.11:1.5.ref: ‘this is how it was in the past,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.
sn42.11:1.5.en: ‘this is how it was in the past,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

sn42.11:1.6.pli: Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, anāgatamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ:
sn42.11:1.6.ref: If I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the future, saying
sn42.11:1.6.en: If I were to teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering in the future, saying

sn42.11:1.7.pli: ‘evaṁ bhavissati anāgatamaddhānan’ti, tatrāpi te siyā kaṅkhā, siyā vimati.
sn42.11:1.7.ref: ‘this is how it will be in the future,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.
sn42.11:1.7.en: ‘this is how it will be in the future,’ you might have doubts or uncertainties about that.

sn42.11:1.8.pli: Api cāhaṁ, gāmaṇi, idheva nisinno ettheva te nisinnassa dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi.
sn42.11:1.8.ref: Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there.
sn42.11:1.8.en: Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and disappearance of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there.

sn42.11:1.9.pli: Taṁ suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn42.11:1.9.ref: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
sn42.11:1.9.en: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn42.11:1.10.pli: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho bhadrako gāmaṇi bhagavato paccassosi.

sn42.11:2.2.pli: atthi te uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:2.2.ref: Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:2.2.en: Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:2.3.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:2.4.pli: “Atthi pana te, gāmaṇi, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:2.4.ref: “But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:2.4.en: “But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:2.5.pli: “Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:2.6.pli: “Ko nu kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ko paccayo yena te ekaccānaṁ uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:2.6.ref: “What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?”
sn42.11:2.6.en: “What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?”

sn42.11:2.7.pli: “Yesaṁ me, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, atthi me tesu chandarāgo.
sn42.11:2.7.ref: “The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I have desire and passion.
sn42.11:2.7.en: “The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I have desire and passion.

sn42.11:2.8.pli: Yesaṁ pana, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, natthi me tesu chandarāgo”ti.
sn42.11:2.8.ref: The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t have desire and passion.”
sn42.11:2.8.en: The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t have desire and passion.”

sn42.11:2.9.pli: “Iminā tvaṁ, gāmaṇi, dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgate nayaṁ nehi:
sn42.11:2.9.ref: “With this present phenomenon that you have seen, understood, immediately attained, and fathomed, you can apply the same method to the past and future:
sn42.11:2.9.en: “With this present phenomenon that you have seen, understood, immediately attained, and fathomed, you can apply the same method to the past and future:

sn42.11:2.10.pli: ‘yaṁ kho kiñci atītamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajji sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:2.10.ref: ‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:2.10.en: ‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:2.11.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.
sn42.11:2.11.en: For desire is the root of suffering.

sn42.11:2.12.pli: Yampi hi kiñci anāgatamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjissati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:2.12.ref: All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:2.12.en: All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:2.13.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’”
sn42.11:2.13.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’”

sn42.11:2.15.ref: How well said this was by the Buddha!
sn42.11:2.15.en: How well said this was by the Buddha!

sn42.11:2.16.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:2.16.ref: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:2.16.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:2.17.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’
sn42.11:2.17.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’

sn42.11:2.18.pli: Atthi me, bhante, ciravāsī nāma kumāro bahi āvasathe paṭivasati.
sn42.11:2.18.ref: I have a boy called Ciravāsi, who resides in a house away from here.
sn42.11:2.18.en: I have a boy called Ciravāsi, who resides in a house away from here.

sn42.11:2.19.pli: So khvāhaṁ, bhante, kālasseva vuṭṭhāya purisaṁ uyyojemi:
sn42.11:2.19.ref: I rise early and dispatch someone, saying:
sn42.11:2.19.en: I rise early and dispatch someone, saying:

sn42.11:2.20.ref: ‘Go, my man, and check on my boy Ciravāsi.’
sn42.11:2.20.en: ‘Go, my man, and check on my boy Ciravāsi.’

sn42.11:2.21.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhante, so puriso nāgacchati, tassa me hoteva aññathattaṁ:
sn42.11:2.21.ref: Until they get back I worry:
sn42.11:2.21.en: Until they get back I worry:

sn42.11:3.2.pli: ciravāsissa kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:3.2.ref: If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:3.2.en: If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:3.3.pli: “Ciravāsissa me, bhante, kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:3.4.ref: “This too is a way to understand:
sn42.11:3.4.en: “This too is a way to understand:

sn42.11:3.5.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:3.5.ref: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:3.5.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:3.6.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’
sn42.11:3.6.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’

sn42.11:4.2.pli: yadā te ciravāsimātā adiṭṭhā ahosi, assutā ahosi, te ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṁ vā”ti?
sn42.11:4.2.ref: Before you’d seen or heard of Ciravāsi’s mother, did you have any desire or passion or fondness for her?”
sn42.11:4.2.en: Before you’d seen or heard of Ciravāsi’s mother, did you have any desire or passion or fondness for her?”

sn42.11:4.4.pli: “Dassanaṁ vā te, gāmaṇi, āgamma savanaṁ vā evaṁ te ahosi:
sn42.11:4.4.ref: “Then was it because you saw or heard of her that you had
sn42.11:4.4.en: “Then was it because you saw or heard of her that you had

sn42.11:4.5.pli: ‘ciravāsimātuyā chando vā rāgo vā pemaṁ vā’”ti?
sn42.11:4.5.ref: desire or passion or fondness for her?”
sn42.11:4.5.en: desire or passion or fondness for her?”

sn42.11:5.2.pli: ciravāsimātuyā te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
sn42.11:5.2.ref: If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
sn42.11:5.2.en: If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”

sn42.11:5.3.pli: “Ciravāsimātuyā me, bhante, vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.

sn42.11:5.4.ref: “This too is a way to understand:
sn42.11:5.4.en: “This too is a way to understand:

sn42.11:5.5.pli: ‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ.
sn42.11:5.5.ref: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.
sn42.11:5.5.en: ‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire.

sn42.11:5.6.ref: For desire is the root of suffering.’”
sn42.11:5.6.en: For desire is the root of suffering.’”
